thread.title: Wikileaks warns is about to leak CIA chief's emails
thread.title_full: Wikileaks warns is about to leak CIA chief's emails

title: Wikileaks warns is about to leak CIA chief's emails
text:
Wikileaks warns is about to leak CIA chief's emails October 21, 2015 CIA director John Brennan, pictured on March 13, 2015, has an AOL email account hacked 
Anti-secrecy campaign Wikileaks boasted Wednesday that it had obtained CIA director John Brennan's personal emails and was about to make them public. 
The claim came shortly after it was reported that a teenaged hacker had broken into the US spymaster's AOL account and had taken mails and personal data. 
The FBI and Secret Service are investigating the claims, which, if true, would be a major humiliation for US intelligence after a string of major leaks. 
"ANNOUNCE: We have obtained the contents of CIA Chief John Brennan's email account and will be releasing it shortly," the @Wikileaks Twitter account said. 
The account has been verified by Twitter as belonging to the organization and is widely assumed to be controlled by Wikileaks' founder Julian Assange. 
The announcement was made shortly after 1600 GMT and it was not clear when any material would go online, but Wikileaks has a track record of secret document dumps. 
Earlier this week the New York Post reported that a hacker, who described himself as an American high school student, had called reporters to describe his exploits. 
He claimed Brennan's private email account held sensitive files, including his 47-page application for security clearance. 
Then, using his purported Twitter account—@phphax—the hacker taunted authorities with redacted images of what appeared to be government information. 
The Twitter account claims the hacker is 13 years old, and expresses support for the Palestinian cause. 
The US government has been dogged in recent years by high-profile leaks, including a trove of diplomatic cables published by Wikileaks. 
Senior officials have also been criticized for not properly protecting sensitive and classified documents. 
Former CIA chief David Petraeus was forced to plead guilty to improperly handling documents after it emerged that he loaned his mistress his Afghan war diaries. 
And presidential candidate Hillary Clinton is under fire after she admitted that she only used a private email server during her time as Secretary of State. WikiLeaks releases mystery file September 1, 2011 
WikiLeaks released a mysterious encrypted file on Wednesday after telling its followers on Twitter to stand by for "an important announcement." WikiLeaks fundraising stunt draws Anonymous ire October 12, 2012

WikiLeaks on Thursday released 276,394 new documents from the hack of Sony Pictures in what could be a further embarrassment for the Japanese media and electronics group. State Dept. to release 7,000 pages of emails, 150 censored August 31, 2015 
The State Department will release roughly 7,000 pages of Hillary Rodham Clinton's emails Monday, including about 150 emails that have been censored because they contain information that is now deemed classified. "Can you hear me now?" Snowden joins Twitter, follows NSA September 29, 2015 
Edward Snowden, who has confounded U.S. officials since his abrupt departure from the country two years ago, has just found a new megaphone in Twitter. Hacker claims to have breached CIA director's personal email October 19, 2015 
An anonymous hacker claims to have breached CIA Director John Brennan's personal email account and has posted documents online, including a list of email addresses purportedly from Brennan's contact file.
